thread.title: Airline disasters: A reason not to fly with certain airlines?
thread.title_full: Airline disasters: A reason not to fly with certain airlines?

author: Amelia Romanos
title: Airline disasters: A reason not to fly with certain airlines?
text:
Airline disasters: A reason not to fly with certain airlines? AMELIA ROMANOS Last updated 11:15, October 22 2015 DAMIR SAGOLJ/REUTERS 
Malaysia Airlines planes are seen on the tarmac at the Kuala Lumpur International Airport. 
There's a certain "eek" expression that comes with travel talk about Germanwings, Malaysia Airlines and other companies linked to air disasters. 
I saw it first hand when a couple of friends flew Malaysia Airlines to Bali a few weeks after flight MH370 disappeared in 2014. 
They'd paid for their travel before it happened and didn't seriously consider cancelling, but the airline was clearly not a forgotten detail as they headed off. 
I saw the expression again recently when a colleague told me she was flying from Croatia to London with Germanwings. 
She booked the flight months after the French Alps crash, and cost was apparently a deciding factor. 
Another workmate said given the choice, and a couple of dollars difference, she would have chosen another airline. 
I faced the decision in December when a travel agent, booking my flight from London to New Zealand, hesitantly asked if I would mind flying Malaysia Airlines. 
This was after the airline's second tragedy, the shooting down of MH17 over Ukraine, so it must have become policy for them to ask.
